awd_titl_txt: A Novel Platform for the Tunable Production of Proteoglycans
awd_abstract_narration:
On the surface of most all mammalian cells are proteins that have amino and sugar groups (glycosaminoglycan; GAGs) attached as side chains. These proteins, known as proteoglycans, are important to human health. How the structure of these proteins influences their function is still poorly understood. We will develop a tobacco cell that can be tuned to produced different GAGs so the relationships between chain length, GAG composition, and core protein on function can be understood more clearly. The ability to control the production of GAGs with defined structure will enhanced their potential use in therapeutic applications.  Undergraduate and graduate students will be trained, and students from underrepresented groups will be actively recruited to perform research in the labs. Students will gain expertise that will better prepare them for productive participation in the expanding biomanufacturing workforce.

The overall objective of this project is to demonstrate the production of the core proteoglycan structure in tobacco without sulfation or other modifications. To accomplish this, we will need to expand the molecular tool box for plant synthetic biology, enabling additional control over protein expression. The long-term goal is to develop a proteoglycan production platform in N. benthamiana that will enable us to produce proteoglycans with defined GAGs, chain length, composition and core proteins. This modular approach to proteoglycan production will enable future discoveries into the structure-function relationship of proteoglycans in a variety of biological contexts. Which in turn will allow for the development of a new class of functional biological macromolecules, fostering a revolution in the field of glycomics.  This novel technology will enable researchers to explore the enormous, untapped potential of GAGs and proteoglycans for the development of new biological and medical technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project “A novel platform for the tunable production of proteoglycans” aimed to use plants such as wild tobacco as a new source to produce proteoglycans.  Proteoglycans are a diverse class of biomolecules that contain proteins and polysaccharides. Proteoglycans are found in many human tissues where they perform a wide variety of essential functions.  The polysaccharide heparin is an important component of some proteoglycans and is used clinically as an anticoagulant. Currently heparin is produced by isolating it from animal tissues. Despite their importance in human health our understanding of how proteoglycan structure drive’s function is still lacking.  This project worked to develop a platform for producing proteoglycans with varying structures in plants to understand this structure-function linkage.  Plants do not produce proteoglycans naturally, so being able to control their production in a plant would provide a completely novel source for proteoglycans with defined structures that could be used for discovery of their interactions or production of therapeutic molecules like heparin. Progress and accomplishments on the project included optimization of a protein production system in wild tobacco, developing and troubleshooting ways to add the first sugars that initiate the polysaccharide addition to a model proteoglycan called, serglycin, chemical synthesis of variants of the anticoagulant heparin, and investigation of the blood compatibility of these heparin variants.  These results show how which chemical features of heparin determine its anticoagulant activity.  These results will inform future experiments to develop blood-compatible materials. The project aided in the training of five undergraduate students in research related to future career interests.  One of the undergraduate students decided to pursue a graduate education and continued to participate in the project.  These students developed critical thinking and experimentation skills along with scientific communication skills that will help them in their current and future careers.  The project also furthered the training of two post-doctoral scholars who practice mentoring and project management skills along with further development of their communication skills. Results have been disseminated through two conference presentations and one journal article.  There are at least two additional papers being prepared for publication.
